ygData.subject: Re: Placement of conceptually different inputs in HyperNEAT?
ygData.msgSnippet: Thus far, my answer to the questions is as follows: Given an arbitrary point P in design space, comprised of the following: (a) problem specific inputs

Thus far, my answer to the questions is as follows:

Given an arbitrary poi=
nt "P" in design space, comprised of the 
following:
(a) problem specific i=
nputs (PSIs);
(b) auxiliary additional parameters associated w/ PSIs;
(c) p=
roblem specific outputs (PSOs);
(d) auxiliary additional parameters associa=
ted w/ PSOs;

Substrate Inputs: comprised of PSIs, "a" above;
Substrate Out=
puts: comprised of PSOs, "c" above;
 
Hypercube Inputs: comprised of auxili=
ary additional parameters 
associated w/ PSIs & PSOs, "b" & "d" above;
Hype=
rcube Output: weight between current pair of substrate nodes

Your problem =
as stated below works fine as long as the hypercube 
input "from" node is t=
aken from only your substrate 1, and the 
hypercube input "to" node is take=
n from only your substrate 2. The 
topology of the hypercube inputs remains=
 constant. But I think your 
real question, when things are not so nice, co=
uld also be stated as 
follows:

Questions:
(1) When the dimensionality of =
"b" and "d" differ, how is the 
hypercube input topology reconciled?
(2) Ar=
e there different hypercube networks depending on if the 
current node (inp=
ut or output), is a substrate input, hidden or 
output node?
(3) How are su=
bstrate hidden nodes handled when the hypercube is 
focused on the associat=
ed connecting substrate weight? (variation on 
question 2)

If not, how wou=
ld you reword the questions?


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Thomas Johnson=
" <thomas.j.johnson@...> 
wrote:
>
> OK, in case my last explanation wasn't=
 clear, here it is again with 
specific
> answers to your questions:
> For =
the case of a 4-card poker game, with two players, a maximum of 
two
> roun=
ds, and two possible actions by each player in each round
> a) There are tw=
o substrates:
> Substrate 1 represents the card we hold and is a 1x4 grid t=
hat uses 
a
> one-hot encoding for the cards
> Substrate 2 represents the a=
ctions we have observed and is a 2x2x2 
grid. The
> first dimension is the =
round, the second dimension is the player 
who took
> the action, and the 3=
rd dimension is the action taken (bet/fold)
> b) The output is the cell in =
the second substrate for the player 
and round
> that we're interested in t=
hat has the highest activation
> c) The hypercube inputs would be the coord=
inates of each substrate. 
Maybe we
> use 10 inputs in total (2 from, 2 t f=
or the first substrate, 3 
from, 3 to
> for the second substrate).
> d) The=
 output is interpreted as you said: the weight of the 
connection
> between=
 the substrate nodes specified in the input
> 
> Note that this is just one=
 possibility of how to set this up. In 
one sense,
> my question is "for ga=
mes where some of the inputs are in completely
> orthogonal categories, wha=
t are good answers to each of items a-d?"
>

Outputs,

substrate connection between 
current
> > substrate nodes under considerati=
on.

ther alternative I was thinking about was placing it in a

parate

nly two of the outputs would be
